revision.text:
{{Infobox settlement | name = {{raise|0.2em|Jingjiang}} | official_name = | native_name = {{lower|0.1em|{{nobold|{{lang|zh-hans|靖江市}}}}}} | other_name = Tsingkiang | settlement_type = [[County-level city]] | image_skyline = | image_caption = | image_map = | map_caption = Location of the county | pushpin_map = China Jiangsu | pushpin_label_position = left | pushpin_map_caption = Location in Jiangsu | coordinates = {{coord|32.009|N|120.263|E|region:CN-32|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | coordinates_footnotes = <ref>{{Google maps|url=https://www.google.com/maps/place/Jingjiang,+Taizhou,+Jiangsu/@32.0086682,120.2628106,14z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m2!3m1!1s0x35b3fdf1ff2aeb09:0x4eab3d57eb5a4ab6 |title=Jingjiang|accessdate=2014-07-02}}</ref> | subdivision_type = Country | subdivision_name = People's Republic of China | subdivision_type1 = [[Provinces of China|Province]] | subdivision_name1 = [[Jiangsu]] | subdivision_type2 = [[Prefecture-level city]] | subdivision_name2 = [[Taizhou, Jiangsu|Taizhou]] | subdivision_type3 = Subdivisions | subdivision_name3 = | area_footnotes = <ref>Taizhou Statistical Yearbook 2012/{{zh|s=《泰州统计年鉴2012》|labels=no}}.{{in lang|zh}} Accessed 9 July 2014.</ref> | area_total_km2 = 655.60 | elevation_m = | population_footnotes = <ref name="2010 permanent">China 2010 Census County-by-county Statistics/{{zh|s=《中国2010年人口普查分县资料》|labels=no}}.{{in lang|zh}} Accessed 9 July 2014.</ref> | population_total = 684360 | population_density_km2 = auto | timezone = [[China Standard Time|China Standard]] | utc_offset = +8 | postal_code_type = [[List of postal codes in China|Postal code]] | postal_code = 2145XX | website = }} '''Jingjiang''' ({{zh|c=靖江|p=Jìngjiāng}}) is a [[county-level city]] under the administration of [[Taizhou, Jiangsu|Taizhou]], [[Jiangsu]] province, China. It is located on the northern (left) bank of the [[Yangtze River]], and is the southernmost part of Taizhou City, bordering [[Nantong]] to the northeast, [[Suzhou]] to the southeast, [[Wuxi]] to the south, [[Changzhou]] to the southwest, and [[Zhenjiang]] to the west. The area of Jingjiang is 655.6 square kilometres and the population was 684,360 at the 2010 census.
== History == The terrain of Jingjiang nowadays was originated as a shoal in the Yangtze River, which was known '''Matuosha''' in the ancient China. As the shoal had been extended, it was separated from then [[Jiangyin]] county to found a new county in 1471. As being looted by the [[Wokou]] for several time, it is designated '''Jiangjiang''' (means "pacifying the Yangzte River"). <ref name=":1">{{Cite book|script-title=zh:中国历史大辞典·历史地理卷|last=|first=|publisher=Shanghai Cishu Press|year=1996|isbn=7-5326-0299-0|volume=|location=|pages=955|language=zh|trans-title=The Great Encyclopaedia of Chinese history, Volume on Historical Geography}}</ref>
The county under the administration of the prefecture-level city of Yangzhou originally, was converted to a county-level city in 1993, then was transferred to the Taizhou in 1996.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|script-title=zh:江苏市县概况|last=|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=978-7-55-373496-5|location=|pages=398–401|language=zh|trans-title=A Survey of Cities and Counties in Jiangsu|quote=|via=}}</ref>
==Geography== The Yangzte had split into the north and the south distributaries at Jingjiang, but the city merged into the north bank later than the 1610s inasmuch as the north distributary was filled in by continued deposition.<ref name=":1" />
==Transportation== The city is part of the [[Yangtze River Delta]] region and has [[Yangtze River bridges and tunnels|one river crossing]]. The [[Jiangyin Suspension Bridge]], which carries the [[G2 Beijing–Shanghai Expressway]] to [[Jiangyin]], is [[List of longest suspension bridge spans|one of the longest suspension bridges in the world]]. The [[G40 Shanghai–Xi'an Expressway]] to Nanjing and Shanghai also passes through the city.
==Economy== Traditionally, the city has been noted for its core manufacturing industries in electronics, auto parts, biochemicals, textiles and machinery. Emerging industries include shipbuilding and logistics (transport).
Seven major local shipyards, including one of China's largest private shipyards New Century Shipyard and its subsidiary New Time Shipyard; New Yangtze Shipyard, which went public in Singapore in 2007 and it was the first ever China's private shipyard listed on overseas stock exchange; Jiangsu Eastern Shipyard, which was the second China's private shipbuilding company successfully listed on overseas stock exchange, following the footstep of New Yangtze Shipyard.
==Administrative divisions== The city consists of eight towns and one sub-district: * Jingcheng (靖城街道) * Binjiang （滨江新城） * Xinqiao (新桥镇) * Dongxing (东兴镇) * Xieqiao (斜桥镇) * Xilai (西来镇) * Jishi (季市镇) * Gushan (孤山镇) * Shengci (生祠镇) * Maqiao (马桥镇) In addition the city has a provincial level economic development zone (Jingjiang Economic Development Zone).
==School and Education== Middle School: * Jiangsu Jingjiang Senior Middle School * Jiangsu Jingjiang Xieqiao Middle School * Jiangjiang No.1 Middle School * Jingjiang Bingjiang School * Jingjiang Foreign Language School
==Food== The city is noted for its pork jerky and slices, along with steamed soup dumplings filled with crab juices.
==Notable people== *[[Henry Liu]] *[[Tao Siju]] *[[Song Zude]] *[[Younan Xia]]
==References==
